speaker: sharif
utterance: Yeah, what's up, Todd Exactly. I don't have bay'ah to this masjid, and I don't have bay'ah to the imam here, either. And most people, you have bay'ah to the imam. That way you can move around with them. I don't have it.

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: It's such an intimate view of an informant's job. And what we see is how much of a counterterrorism investigation-- at least this case-- is really just someone trying very hard to make friends with a total stranger. So Sharif goes to the mosque, hoping to bump into Khalifa. He asks Khalifa out for coffee, offers him rides.

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: And most of the time, Khalifa just ignores him. Sharif's over-eagerness in all of this is a little hard to watch. He's like the Ned Flanders of FBI stings.

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: He's constantly texting Khalifa. For example, months into the investigation, Sharif sent Khalifa this text. "As-salaam alaikum, Brother K. What's up? Can you assist me in setting up laptops/Facebook? Inshallah." Here's Lyric.

speaker: lyric r. cabral
utterance: You know, he's not supposed to know how to use Facebook at his age, and I think it was a-- the FBI made that suggestion for Sharif to ask Khalifa to help him set up his Facebook page as a way for Sharif to endear himself to Khalifa, in the sense of like, oh, I'm not knowledgeable in this area. Brother, can you please help me?

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: Khalifa did not help his Muslim brother. In fact, after Sharif tried to friend Khalifa several times over months, Khalifa blocked him. Sharif then sent Khalifa a text that said, "Why didn't you answer my request? Since you blocked me, you have to request it from me." Khalifa texted back, "It's not that serious, bro. LOL."

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: It's hard to see how the FBI thought this was ever supposed to work. Sharif was a lot older than Khalifa. His days as a revolutionary with the Black Panthers were decades ago, and not exactly relevant to a much younger white convert.

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: Sharif smoked pot, dressed in street clothes. Khalifa proselytized and wore traditional Islamic garb. Lyric and David say Sharif was angry that the FBI hadn't done enough to make him seem believable.

speaker: david felix sutcliffe
utterance: He was really frustrated that the FBI didn't have a cover for him. You know, he said, if I had been a businessman, I could have used that as an entryway and say, oh, Khalifa, you want to set up a shop. And Khalifa did want to set up a shop, I think, a breakfast cafe for people to go to after morning prayer.

speaker: david felix sutcliffe
utterance: And Sharif would say, like, if I had a businessman cover, you know, I could use that as a way to kind of like to keep the conversation going and eventually get to a point where we're talking about money, and you know, what are you going to do for money? If I do this for you, what would you do for me?

speaker: david felix sutcliffe
utterance: There just wasn't like a specific foothold. There wasn't like anything specifically related to Sharif's cover that would initiate an organic conversation about these issues. From what I can tell, it seems to come out of left field every single time.

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: For example, one day, as Sharif explains in the film, he was talking with Khalifa, and the classic holy war conversation-starter, camping, came up.

speaker: sharif

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: Sharif was supposed to gather evidence, record his conversations for FBI analysis. But when he did manage to speak to Khalifa, he couldn't get Khalifa to say anything that Khalifa hadn't already revealed himself on his Facebook page. So he tried other methods that are familiar, if you've ever followed these kinds of cases.

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: He asked Khalifa to buy him a gun. Sharif said that he needed protection from neighborhood kids who were selling drugs in front of his house. Khalifa didn't bite on that, either.

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: But the FBI wanted Sharif to keep going. He would text the FBI to tell them what he was up to. "Heading to Friday prayer at al-Noor Mosque. No word from POI."

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: The FBI would text back, "POI just walked in. Turn recorder on before you go in. Talk to him a little. Get a feel."

speaker: president george w. bush
utterance: Terrorists who commit these acts and those who harbor them.

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: One Sunday night, three months into the investigation, something happened that shows just how hard it is to appear authentic in a situation that's completely fake.

speaker: woman on tv
utterance: She wants out. She asked for--

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: Lyric and David were filming Sharif in his apartment, watching TV, and Sharif sent this text. "ASA." That's short for As-salaam alaikum. "ASA, Brother K. Check this movie on channel 370, Showtime." And then in parentheses, Sharif adds, "Homeland."

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: Khalifa texts back, "Hm, on Netflix?" Sharif responds, "No, Showtime. It's called Homeland. Taliban Warrior." A 63-year-old former Black Panther with decades of experience as a government informant, and the thing he does is text his target about Homeland.

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: By late January 2012, four months into Sharif's involvement in the investigation, Khalifa still hadn't said or done anything that the FBI could use to charge him. No support for terrorism, no plans to engage in any illegal activity.

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: And then one day, Lyric and David saw something on Khalifa's Facebook page that made it clear that this whole game was make-believe. This idea that Sharif was some kind of terrorist recruiter was crumbling.

utterance: Um, I believe his first sort of public inkling that something was wrong, he wrote, "The Feds must think I'm Willie Lump Lump. They think they can send anyone to me." And we knew that that was an indirect reference to Sharif on the ground in Pittsburgh.

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: And then on March 9, 2012, Khalifa posted the following, which he also sent out via email to a bunch of reporters. Quote, "Sometime in September or October of 2011, I met Saeed S. Torres, who introduced himself to me as Sharif."

speaker: lyric r. cabral
utterance: And from there, he goes on to make a detailed discovery that Saeed Sharif Torres is in fact an FBI informant. speaker: lyric r. cabral
utterance: All right, you ready?

speaker: khalifa al-akili
utterance: So he, like, kept wanting to talk to me, even like when we got together or whatever. He wanted to-- so how did you like it? What do you think about it? What do you think about, you know, blowing this up? And just talking crazy.

utterance: Let's take a moment here and just count up all the lies that are being told. Lyric and David are lying to Khalifa, pretending they've never met Sharif. But now they're also lying to Sharif, because they don't tell him that they're interviewing Khalifa.

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: And of course, this whole story began with a lie. Sharif heard from Lyric that he was working for the FBI. And he hid from the FBI that he'd let Lyric and David film the investigation. And Sharif lied to Khalifa about who he really was. It's turned into this giant knot of lies.

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: Once Lyric and David had done their interviews with Khalifa, and gotten away without him figuring out who they really were, they had to keep the lies up. If they did, they could be charged with tampering with an active investigation.

speaker: lyric r. cabral

speaker: jonathan menjivar

speaker: khalifa al-akili

speaker: lyric r. cabral

And so he's looking at a two-year-old transcript that is part of the public record that lists this telephone number from Muhammad as belonging to FBI informant Shahed Hussain.

utterance: I haven't done anything to anybody.

speaker: khalifa al-akili

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: The FBI arrested Khalifa not for terrorism charges, but on a gun charge. Khalifa, remember, was a felon. He'd done time for a narcotics charge. So he wasn't legally supposed to possess a firearm. But one day, years before, he went to a public firing range, borrowed a friend's gun, and shot at a target. His friend took a seven-second video and emailed it to Khalifa.

speaker: lyric r. cabral
utterance: And basically, that friend was called in to the grand jury, and basically, the friend had to admit, yes, I emailed this photo to Khalifa. Yes, this photo was taken at a shooting range, wherein Khalifa was holding a gun. And that's all the information they needed, in combination with that photo, led to confirmation that Khalifa was indeed a felon in possession of a firearm. And he received a sentence of eight years.

speaker: david felix sutcliffe
utterance: And yet his public defender, who said she's handled thousands of gun cases throughout her career, she said she has never once seen someone being prosecuted based on a photograph of them at a gun range. You know, the vast majority of the time, it's someone who's caught in criminal activity.

speaker: jonathan menjivar
utterance: Khalifa had gone to the gun range in 2010, and he hadn't tried to hide it. For a while, a picture of him holding the gun had been his Facebook profile picture. speaker: jonathan menjivar

ep-567.speaker: ira glass
ep-567.utterance: Last year, a tunnel was discovered in Toronto, a secret tunnel. Basically, a conservation official was walking through a wooded ravine in the city and stumbled upon this thing. It was described as sophisticated by police. Tall enough to stand in, 33 feet long, with support beams, a plywood ceiling and walls, water-resistant lighting, a generator and sump pump to pump out groundwater. And at the end of the tunnel, two little rooms were still under construction.

ep-567.speaker: ira glass
ep-567.utterance: Intriguingly, nailed to a wall was a rosary and a plastic red poppy. Canadians use the poppy to commemorate fallen soldiers on Remembrance Day up there. Here in the States, all this got a little bit of coverage, but in Canada it was big news.

ep-567.speaker: reporter
ep-567.utterance: No one knows who dug the 30-foot-long tunnel near the site of this year's Pan-American Games in Toronto.

ep-567.speaker: reporter
ep-567.utterance: A bizarre tunnel found near one of the venues for the upcoming Pan-Am Games has sparked fears of an imminent terror attack.

ep-567.speaker: reporter
ep-567.utterance: Rarely has a dirt tunnel received so much attention.

ep-567.speaker: reporter
ep-567.utterance: No one knows why it was created. Do you think someone told their kid to dig to China and the kid actually tried?

ep-567.speaker: reporter
ep-567.utterance: It's not just the sophistication that police say is troubling, but the lack of suspects or a motive.

ep-567.speaker: ira glass
ep-567.utterance: When something unexplained like this happens, of course, people go nuts speculating about what it could be. That's actually what our program is about today. In this case, the media pondered whether the tunnel would be used to plant a bomb at the upcoming Pan-Am Games nearby. The Pan-Am Games are like an Olympics for North and South and Central America.

ep-567.speaker: ira glass
ep-567.utterance: Or maybe somebody was going to build a meth lab in the tunnel, or an operation to grow marijuana. Or they would use the tunnel to hide foreign athletes from the Pan-Am Games who might want to stay in Canada illegally. On Twitter, it was #terrortunnel. But the truth of what was going on in that tunnel and what its purpose was was nothing like any of that.

ep-567.speaker: ira glass
ep-567.utterance: And the way the Canadian police figured it out-- OK, first of all, can I say, sometimes one is reminded of what a very different country Canada is from the United States. As part of the manhunt for whoever built the tunnel, a policeman tweeted, "If you built a tunnel near the Rexall Centre in Toronto, give us a call, OK?"

ep-567.speaker: ira glass
ep-567.utterance: The Toronto police pointed out that it is not illegal to dig a hole. Apparently, no law was broken. From the start, they said they saw no evidence of terrorism, and they did not want to jump to conclusions. For instance, here's an exchange between then-Toronto deputy chief Mark Saunders and reporters after he showed them a photo of that rosary and plastic poppy.

ep-567.speaker: mark saunders
ep-567.utterance: This was found inside the actual tunnel itself, and it was nailed on the wall.

ep-567.speaker: reporter
ep-567.utterance: What does that tell you?

ep-567.speaker: mark saunders
ep-567.utterance: That tells me that this was nailed inside the tunnel on a wall.

ep-567.speaker: ira glass
ep-567.utterance: The police basically went on TV and showed pictures of the stuff that they found in the tunnel-- a ladder, and the generator, and the sump pump. And they asked the public, this jog anybody's memory? Anybody know anything about this stuff? And that turned out to be exactly that move. Because watching that coverage was a guy named Boko Marich. He sees that ladder--

ep-567.speaker: boko marich
ep-567.utterance: And I said to myself, that look exactly my step-ladder, and I bet you any money this is mine.

ep-567.speaker: ira glass
ep-567.utterance: I bet you any money this is mine.

ep-567.speaker: boko marich
ep-567.utterance: And then when I saw sump pump. And I said, oh-ho-ho, my step-ladder and sump pump. But I couldn't believe. I couldn't believe. Like, I couldn't believe myself. I couldn't sleep. I was thinking about that.

ep-567.speaker: ira glass
ep-567.utterance: He couldn't sleep, because he knew who he'd given the stuff to. Bob is a contractor, and he lent that stuff to one of his favorite employees, this young guy, just 22, Elton. What was Elton doing? And come to think it, Elton had been asking to borrow a lot of tools lately.

ep-567.speaker: boko marich
ep-567.utterance: He was asking me for shovel, for pick, for another shovel, another tool, so many tools. I just would say, OK, if you need, take.

ep-567.utterance: That's actually exactly what happened to me. It's funny you brought that up. I should be a senior now, and I'm still not graduating. ep-567.speaker: sarah gonzales
ep-567.utterance: The only thing that I would change in that is the "allowed" part. People, even with good intentions, unintentionally blame victims or survivors. ep-567.speaker: sarah gonzales
ep-567.utterance: On average, it takes seven to nine times for someone to leave. So just because someone went back doesn't mean that they're never going to leave.

ep-567.utterance: I mean, every time we get into a fight and things start getting really bad, I'm just sitting there, like, you should be leaving right now, you need to get your stuff, you need to get out the door, you need to go home. ep-567.utterance: I mean, I do, and I don't understand the answer. Because it doesn't make sense why being happy 5% of the time makes you stay. I don't know.

ep-567.speaker: sarah gonzales
ep-567.utterance: You know, you do love your partner, right? And so a lot of times, what you really want is just for the abuse to stop, but you still want to be with your partner.

ep-567.speaker: sarah gonzales
ep-567.utterance: Well, you can say, OK, I should be leaving. And if you don't, it's just like, today wasn't the day that I was leaving. As opposed to blaming yourself, because then that might keep you there a little longer. It's like, OK, it didn't happen today, but it can happen tomorrow.

ep-567.speaker: elizabeth
ep-567.utterance: Lorraine, what are you doing with your life? I know you're at that boy's house--

ep-567.speaker: rainy
ep-567.utterance: My assigned counselor has been leaving me voicemails. I never even listened to them.

ep-567.speaker: elizabeth
ep-567.utterance: So don't shut down because you're with this boy. We already spoke about this. The weather was bad. You don't do snow-- I know all your excuses in the book. But right now, the weather's better, so you should have been here today. So, obviously, if I don't see later, that means it's not good. OK? So call me or show up. Bye.
